raw_text:
Baron Kinnock makes Lords debut
 
 Former Labour leader Neil Kinnock has officially been made a life peer during a ceremony in the House of Lords.
 
 He will be known Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty - after his former constituency. Lord Kinnock - who led Labour from 1983 until 1992 - was until recently one of Britain's EU commissioners. A former critic of the House of Lords, he has said he will use the Upper House to advocate its reform and to talk on issues like higher education. "I accepted the kind invitation to enter the House of Lords as a working peer for practical political reasons," he said when his peerage was first announced. "It is a good base for campaigning on national issues like education, sustainable transport, industrial change and the ageing society and global concerns, particularly poverty and oppression." During his induction into the Upper House, Lord Kinnock was accompanied by Lords Leader Baroness Amos and Baroness Royall of Blaisdon, a former aide to the ex-Labour leader. It has been a long journey for the new Lord Kinnock from his earliest days as a rebellious youngster in the south Wales valleys. Born in 1942 in Tredegar to a miner father and nurse mother, he attended Lewis Boys' School in nearby Pengam, known then as the "Eton of the valleys". From there he went to Cardiff University, where he met his future wife Glenys, now a Labour MEP.
 
 After a brief career as a tutor for the Workers' Educational Association, he became an MP at the age of just 28 for his home seat of Bedwellty (later Islwyn). He gained a reputation as a left-wing firebrand, voting against his own Labour government's spending cuts proposals in 1975, and later rejecting a junior post in James Callaghan's administration. But he joined the shadow cabinet in 1980, and after Labour's heavy defeat in the 1983 he was elected leader. He took on the far-left Militant Tendency and began the long process of returning his party to the centre ground. He was not expected to win the 1987 election, when Margaret Thatcher was still riding high, but was bitterly disappointed to lose the next one in 1992 to John Major, and stepped down. He remained an MP until 1995, when he resigned to become European commission for transport. Four years later he became vice-president of the European Commission, with responsibility for internal reform. As he assumes the title of Lord Kinnock, he has also become chairman of the British Council, which promotes the UK's reputation for arts, science and education.
llama3.2:1b: Neil Kinnock was made a life peer in the House of Lords during a ceremony. He is known Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty, after his former constituency. Lord Kinnock will use his position to advocate reforms and discuss issues like higher education and poverty. He previously served as a Labour leader from 1983-1992 and was EU commissioner until recently, when he resigned.
llama3.2:3b: Neil Kinnock has been made a life peer as Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty and will serve in the House of Lords, where he plans to advocate for its reform and discuss national issues such as higher education. He was a Labour leader from 1983-1992 and later served as an EU commissioner.
gemma2:2b: Neil Kinnock was appointed a life peer as Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty. He will use his new position in the House of Lords to advocate for reforms and talk about issues like education. He has said he accepts the position for practical political reasons as it offers access to address national issues like poverty and oppression.  He reflects on his long career, from a rebellious youth in Wales to becoming Labour leader and later European Commission member.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Lord Kinnock was made a life peer during his induction into the Upper House of the House of Lords after serving as a Labour leader. He became a member of both Houses of Parliament. 

The text provides general background about the Baroness Amos and her role in making Neil Kinnock the new Lord Kinnock. It explains that Kinnock was born in 1942, attended Lewis Boys' School (now called "Eton of the valleys"), and later joined his father's side as a miner for his home seat of Bedwellty. He gained recognition as a left-wing firebrand before joining the Labour Party, which he had previously opposed.

The text also details Kinnock's long career in politics, including:

- Serving as a Labour leader from 1983 to 1992
- Being elected as an MP for his home seat of Bedwellty (later Islwyn)
- Resigning from the position of British Council chairman due to the UK losing its EU membership bid

In summary, Baron Kinnock is making a transition into the House of Lords after being made a life peer following his induction.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Former Labour leader Neil Kinnock becomes a life peer in the House of Lords after 20 years away from politics, taking over as chairman of the British Council and vice-president of the European Commission.
qwen2.5:3b: Former Labour leader Neil Kinnock has been made a life peer in the House of Lords as Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty. Known for his criticism of the Upper House earlier in his career, he intends to use it for reform and issues such as higher education. He accepted the position due to its potential for political campaigning on national issues like transportation, industrial change, and global concerns. Born into a mining family in Wales, Kinnock rose through the Labour party ranks, becoming leader after winning crucial elections but eventually losing his subsequent leadership bid. Now Lord Kinnock also serves as chairman of the British Council.

smollm:1.7b:
Baron Neil Kinnock was officially made a life peer during a ceremony in the House of Lords on 21 January 2019. He will be known as Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty - after his former constituency in South Wales. Lord Kinnock, who led Labour from 1983 until 1992, was until recently one of Britain's EU commissioners. A former critic of the House of Lords, he has said he will use the Upper House to advocate its reform and to talk on issues like higher education. "I accepted the kind invitation to enter the House of Lords as a working peer for practical political reasons," he said when his peerage was first announced. "It is a good base for campaigning on national issues like education, sustainable transport, industrial change and the aging society and global concerns, particularly poverty and oppression." During his induction into the Upper House, Lord Kinnock was accompanied by Lords Leader Baroness Amos and Baroness Royall of Blaisdon, a former aide to the ex-Labour leader. It has been a long journey for the new Lord Kinnock from his earliest days as a rebellious youngster in the south Wales valleys. Born in 1942 in Tredegar to a miner father and nurse mother, he attended Lewis Boys' School in Bedwellty (later Islwyn). From there he went to Cardiff University, where he met his future wife Glenys, now a Labour MEP.
 
 After a brief career as a tutor for the Workers' Educational Association, he became an MP at the age of just 28 for his home seat of Bedwellty (later Islwyn). He gained a reputation as a left-wing firebrand, voting against his own Labour government's spending cuts proposals in 1975 and later rejecting a junior post in James Callaghan's administration. But he joined the shadow cabinet in 1980, and after Labour's heavy defeat in the 1983 election, he was elected leader. He took on the far-left Militant Tendency and began the long process of returning his party to the centre ground. He was not expected to win the 1987 election, when Margaret Thatcher was still riding high, but was bitterly disappointed to lose the next one in 1992 to John Major, and stepped down. He remained an MP until 1995, when he resigned to become European commission for transport. Four years later he became chairman of the British Council, which promotes the UK's reputation for arts, science and education.

Lord Kinnock has been officially made a life peer of the House of Lords, following his former Labour status as Neil Kinnock. He will be known as Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty (or Bedworth). Lord Kinnock, now a former EU Commissioner, plans to advocate for reforms on issues such as higher education, sustainable transport, industrial change, and aging society. His journey began with his youth in south Wales valleys, where he attended Lewis Boys' School and later studied at Cardiff University. He met his future wife, Glenys, during his studies, who remains a Labour MEP. Lord Kinnock was an MP aged 28 and became the Labour leader in 1983, facing significant political challenges and leaving office in 1995 to hold the title of Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty. Currently, he chairs the British Council, promoting UK reputation in arts, science, and education.
tinyllama:1.1b: In a ceremony held in the House of Lords on June 28th, former Labour leader Neil Kinnock was made a life peer by becoming Baron Kinocck of Bedwellty, after his former constituency. Kinocck took up his new position with the intention of advocating for reforms and issues like education, sustainable transport, industrial change, and global concerns, particularly poverty and oppression, during his time in the House of Lords. During his induction into the Upper House, Kinocck was accompanied by Baroness Amos, who is the current Leader of the House of Lords. Kinocck's journey started at the age of 28 when he became an MP for his home seat, Bedwellty, in the Welsh Valleys constituency, before gaining a reputation as a left-wing firebrand, voting against his own Labour government's spendcut proposals in 1975. However, he also joined the shadow cabinet and eventually returned to lead the centre-ground Labour party in the 1980 general election defeat. Kinocck's final position was vice-president of the European Commission, where he overseeled internal reform for four years before resigning in 1995 to take up the title of Lord Kinocck and become chairman of the British Council, promoting UK's representation for arts, science, and education.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Baron Kinnock, a former Labour leader, is made a life peer in a ceremonial event at the House of Lords. He will take the title "Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty" as a result. Born in 1942, he attended Lewis Boys' School in Pengam and later received his degree from Cardiff University. During his time there, he was involved with groups like the Workers' Educational Association (WEA) and became an MP at the age of 28. He served under Prime Ministers James Callaghan and Margaret Thatcher, but was defeated in the 1983 election. In 1987, he led the Labour party back to power. After resigning from politics, he became the European commission for transport in 1992. Four years later, he returned to politics as a vice-president of the European Commission responsible for internal reform. Kinnock now takes on the title of Lord Kinnock and assumes the role of chairman of the British Council, which promotes the UK's reputation for arts, science, and education.

He joined the shadow cabinet in 1980 and was elected leader after Labour's heavy defeat in 1983. granite3.1-dense:2b:
Former Labour leader Neil Kinnock, born in 1942 to a miner and nurse in south Wales, was officially made a life peer (Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty) during a ceremony in the House of Lords. Previously known as Lord Kinnock upon his tenure as Britain's EU commissioner for transport from 1995 to 2004, he will now use the title in the Upper House for practical political reasons, focusing on national issues like higher education and global concerns such as poverty.

Kinnock, known for his left-wing stance, served as an MP from 1974 until 1985, gaining a reputation as a government critic. He led Labour from 1983 to 1992, restoring the party from its far-left roots to the center ground after facing harsh defeats in the late 1970s and early 1980s. After stepping down as an MP, he joined the European Commission, rising to vice-president with internal reform responsibilities. In 2005, he became chairman of the British Council.

Kinnock's journey to becoming a life peer began in his early years, attending prestigious schools and Cardiff University before entering politics as an MP at 28. His career marked by challenges against spending cuts and opposition to junior roles in Tory administrations, Kinnock eventually led Labour back into power in 1992 but lost the 1993 election to John Major.
reference: Former Labour leader Neil Kinnock has officially been made a life peer during a ceremony in the House of Lords.During his induction into the Upper House, Lord Kinnock was accompanied by Lords Leader Baroness Amos and Baroness Royall of Blaisdon, a former aide to the ex-Labour leader.Lord Kinnock - who led Labour from 1983 until 1992 - was until recently one of Britain's EU commissioners.A former critic of the House of Lords, he has said he will use the Upper House to advocate its reform and to talk on issues like higher education.It has been a long journey for the new Lord Kinnock from his earliest days as a rebellious youngster in the south Wales valleys.He will be known Baron Kinnock of Bedwellty - after his former constituency.As he assumes the title of Lord Kinnock, he has also become chairman of the British Council, which promotes the UK's reputation for arts, science and education."I accepted the kind invitation to enter the House of Lords as a working peer for practical political reasons," he said when his peerage was first announced.
